segments.text: She never spoke to her sister about the moment she was thrown out of her home, nor about the time leading up to it, during which she often had to manage the pink house alone before she was even 17, cleaning and organizing rooms, doing laundry, cooking, watering Lucy's garden so it wouldn't wilt, clinging to the house almost like a lifeline that might eventually bring her to safety.
That didn't happen, but she never reproached her sister without being prepared for it.
All the events that led to what happened started surfacing in her memory.
Ten years separated them.
She was the daughter of Lucy's first husband, whom she first met when she was ten.
He lived in Bogota, Colombia, doing business there.
Shortly before her sister got married, he came to the country for the event.
A well-groomed man.
Slightly Polish in appearance, but pleasant-mannered.
Their relationship was always distant, not emotionally, but physically.
From the day Liora was two and a half and Yosif, Lucy and she moved to Ashkelon.
Her older sister was sent, as was customary in those years, to a boarding school.
At first she was at Ben Shemin and then at Kabut's Ramat Yohanan, where she stayed until her enlistment in the IDF.
Lucy explained that there wasn't yet a school for her age in the Afrodar neighborhood of Ashkelon.
And besides, her daughter had friends going to that same boarding school, and she wanted to join them.
Thus she had an older sister mainly during holidays or weekends.
They loved each other very much, but as the years went by, the age gap between them became evident.
When she turned eight, her sister was already a soldier.
At ten, she was already married.
And when Leora was eleven, she became an aunt for the first time.
She was too young to delve into her older sister's soul, a little girl who had already experienced her parents' divorce, which she heard was quiet.

and then had to bond with her mother's new partner, witness the great love between them, their wedding ceremony, and two weeks later, his murder by Arabs from Jaffa at the Hawaii Cafe he owned and see her mother shattered.
As if that wasn't enough, her father moved to live on the other side of the world.
What emotional burden does an eight-year-old girl carry, having experienced so many upheavals in her short life?
There's no doubt she had many moments of loneliness and longing, perhaps even a sense of being abandoned in some kibbutz and forgotten, even if it wasn't so.
Nevertheless, nothing could prepare Leora for her older sister's behavior during the months Lucy, their mother, was hospitalized at a Suda.
She knew her mother lay on her deathbed, but rarely visited.
She had two small children then, but she lived only ten minutes from the hospital.
She could have found time to visit her mother, just as Lucy had consistently found time to visit her almost weekly, coming by cab from Ashkelon, loaded with gifts to fill her fridge.
Her older sister behaved in that period with emotional insensitivity.
Yet even though Leora witnessed her behavior, she could never have envisioned, even in her worst nightmares, what happened after Lucy's death.
Her older sister sat Shiva alone in her apartment in Givitayam.
The one her father bought her upon her marriage, she justified it by saying she was a mother of two small children.
Yosef found it quite acceptable, as he didn't attach much importance to religious rituals.
The sorrow is inside us, he said.

And so on the fourth day of the Shiva, as neighbors, acquaintances, and even distant visitors came in, a man and a woman, two strangers, entered, introducing themselves as lawyers, and wanted to speak with Yosef privately.
She recalls her antennas, focusing on the woman's thin, almost malicious lips and the man's bald head.
They sat with Josef at a side table in the dining room.
And after a few minutes of conversation, she saw him pale and his eyes darken.
You've gone mad.
He shouted loudly.
Where does she think I'll get that from?
We're drowning in debt up to our necks because of the hospital stay at Asuda and the loan we took three years ago when we added rooms to the hotel.
I'm turning worlds.
Upside down to cover it every month.
Tell her to come and talk to me and we'll see what we can do.
She has no idea what she's talking about."
After they left, he sat stunned at the side table.
Something in his darkened eyes and his expressions shifting between anger and bewilderment kept her from approaching him.
Until finally, she gathered the courage, went to him, and put her hand on his shoulder.
What happened, Daddy?"
she asked.
He looked at her as if seeing her for the first time, realizing she heard at least part of the conversation, the part where he raised his voice.
How do you explain to a not yet sixteen-year-old girl, mature and wise as she may be, that her older sister is asking for her share of Lucy's inheritance?
an inheritance mostly consisting of debts and payments, large portions arising from that private hospitalization at a suitor, with a professor constantly attending to Lucy.
A week later, when they visited Lucy's grave, her sister arrived with her husband.
Leora still didn't fully understand what was happening, but saw her father, Josef, sit with them after returning from the cemetery, along with his close friend Gorin, a respected lawyer in the town.
Joseph gently tried to explain the situation, backing his explanations with documents from the hospital and the bank.
He understood she wanted her share, but at the moment, there was nothing to distribute.
First, they needed to get out of debt and recover.
Then, maybe something could be done.
She heard her sister's husband raise his voice, saying it was out of the question.
After a lengthy silence, Gorin said, OK, look, I'll go with Joseph to the bank tomorrow.
We'll try to convince them to give him another loan of 10,000 liras.
It's not guaranteed they'll agree, but for sure they won't give more, and he won't be able to repay.
If they approve, it'll go to you.
Joseph's spirits were heavy.
He wandered around for days, dejected and tired, visibly sleepless at nights.

The bank didn't approve the loan, and her sister's lawyers informed him they weren't interested in the amount he specified, and if he didn't give her her share of the house, they would go for asset liquidation.
This house was the creation of Lucy and him.
They nurtured it with toil and sweat over the years.
A world and more passed through their hands.
And she, the little one, since infancy, was setting the tables, distributing cutlery and napkins, making sure not to get underfoot during busy times.
This house also paid for the boarding school her older sister attended, and they generously ensured she lacked nothing.
He had no idea what to do now.
He still hoped the court would see the lack of logic and injustice in what they asked.
It wasn't just a hotel.
It was their home, his and his sixteen-year-old daughters.
And where would they go?
Leora heard a sigh escape his throat, shot him a worried glance, and remembered the ring story.
Lucy had two rings.
one a diamond solitaire and the other a large square man's ring that opened at the top, hiding a tiny, almost unrecognizable photo of the figure.
She wore it on her right hand's ring finger.
This was the ring of Abraham, her husband, who was murdered two weeks after their wedding.
A few years before her death, while planting sweet peas in the pink house's garden, the ring disappeared in the loose soil and was never found.
The loss broke Lucy's heart.
Months later, in an attempt to comfort her, Yosef took her to the jeweler, where they ordered for her a green emerald ring with a diamond on each side.
These two rings never left her fingers, only after she fell ill and her fingers shrank when she was a constant resident of the hospital.
where the rings placed in a small box and buried deep within her wardrobe section.
After Lucy's funeral, when they returned from the cemetery, Leora went to the wardrobe, took out the green emerald ring, showed it to her sister, and slipped it on her finger.
It's yours, she told her, so you'll always remember mom.
Her sister was moved to tears.
In the evening, after everyone dispersed, she told her father about it.
Joseph didn't say anything.
He wasn't angry, just looked.
At her with sadness and said quietly, A shame you didn't ask me first.
In hindsight, it really was a shame she hadn't asked him about it.
For she soon realized she had hurried and shown too much generosity towards her sister.

While she was thinking about her and making sure she had a memento from their mother, her sister's thoughts were on money she might get from the house's dissolution, rendering her homeless within two and a half years.
In the years that followed, she often encountered the green ring on her sister's finger, recalled it, and felt as though she'd wronged her father.
The behavior of the lawyers representing her sister against them was ruthless.
Cunningly, they prolonged the legal proceedings until Leora turned 18, when she'd be considered an adult, an age at which she could be evicted from her home.
And so it happened.
A week after her enlistment, when she came home for her first leave, she packed her few belongings into two cardboard boxes and returned to the Army.
The following day, the house was handed over to its buyers, leaving her without her pink house, without a home at all.
Please don't ask me to be angry with her, she told her father now, in the cafe, with a sad expression.
Something inside me doesn't allow me to be angry with her.
I've repressed all those painful events to a forgotten corner, so remote that I don't even remember where it is.
Something about everything that happened was beyond all reason, accompanied by so much injustice and completely inexplicable.
And in any case, I couldn't change a thing.
So I chose to continue my life exactly from where they stopped because of her.
And let's admit, I didn't have much choice either.
The strange thing is that instead of being angry, over time I've made room for pity for her.
The stupidity in which she let her husband drag her to these actions.

Her weak character, her lack of backbone to confront him, and that despite all their big hopes for a large inheritance, she's getting pennies much less than what you initially offered her, from what you didn't even have.
And that husband of hers, once he realized he wouldn't get rich from her, got up and left the house, leaving her with three small children, and simply vanished from their lives.
So what is there to be angry for?
After all, she wasn't born mean, she just didn't think about what she was doing, didn't realize she was throwing me out at 18 with nothing.
and mom always said about her that she was a good soul, and in some way I even think she was right.
She has kindness and great dedication, especially towards her children.
You can't keep grudges against people all your life.
I don't have that anger and rage gene.
Maybe I neutralized it, or perhaps I was born without the ability to be angry, and it's a good thing.
I remember you pointing out certain bitter and angry people we hosted in our pink house, saying it's so futile to carry such anger and let it ruin their lives.
They looked at each other in silence.
She had no idea where this speech came from.
It was the first time she verbalized it, and she felt somewhat exhausted.
But the words didn't leave her, and she continued speaking to herself silently, realizing there are things a bit too hard to say out loud.
Perhaps better not uttered.
In her heart she heard herself.
You're right that sometimes it seems as if I turned the other cheek.
But the truth is, it's really not like that.
I don't need anything from her and never did.
I stand on my own two feet.
Don't ask me to be angry with her.
It merely saddens me how her life turned out.
I'm sure if mom is watching from above, it saddens her too.
She doesn't need to worry about me.
She probably knew even before her death that I would be the responsible adult, knowing you can't always be relied on.
And she was right, of course.
Because as you say, there was a time when you sort of raised me, not I you.
But sometimes a bit of anger does rise within me.
And I wonder, what are you thinking?
It's flattering that you trust me like this, but you should know it's not always great fun.
And still, it's hard.
For me to be genuinely angry with you, I remember you before our pink house began to fall apart.
A man full of activity, full of deeds, a man of people.
knowing how to manage, articulate, and in moments of rest, knowing how to paint beautifully.
Before my eyes, I saw the activity engine and you stop, how you faded into yourself, realizing you were about to lose your life's work, and not sure if you had the strength to start anew.
I almost understood your heart and left you alone.
not nagging, not driving you crazy, letting you wander the big city, flirt with whatever moved.
Just could not truly be angry.
None of what happened was deserved.

When I think about it, you were a young man of 46, left widowed with a not yet 16-year-old child, helpless, not knowing your right from your left, seemingly waiting for mom to return any moment and take matters into her hands.
I cannot manage to be angry with her, and I probably can never be angry with you, though sometimes it comes for a moment, then immediately passes.
After all, you are my beloved daddy, and even if lately, you haven't really been father of the year.

You've always been a father full of love, so embracing, so proud of me, giving me the feeling there's no one like me, granting me the tools to stand confidently on my feet and not be intimidated by life.
You instilled in me culture, literature and knowledge of art and your paintings surround me.
You even left me mom in the amazing portrait you painted so I could talk to her and with her since she left.
So how can I be angry with you?
But in her heart she speaks only in her heart.
When she lifted her eyes she found him looking at her with a gentle warm and loving gaze.
It seemed to her there was something more in that gaze, perhaps appreciation, something respectful, as if he could hear the continuation of the speech she spoke within herself.
When did you grow up so much?
How did I not notice?
He suddenly said quietly.
You've given quite the life lesson here.
You're right.
In some way, I'd want you to be angry with her, at least a bit, but I'm so glad you don't have that need and that you're not an angry, bitter person.
And most of all, I want you always to remember I love you very much.
Suddenly remembering, he asked, and what did you want to tell me?
She felt the hoarseness in her voice as she replied.
Oh, it's not that important.
It can wait till next time.
She stood up, hugged him tightly and walked away, leaving him to stroll up the boulevard to his home.
